repnme.cdata!:
Timor-Leste - First, Second, and Third
            Community Empowerment and Local Governance Projects; and the
            First and Second Agricultural Rehabilitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Community and Local Governance
            Project (CEP I), the Second Community Empowerment Project
            (CEP II), and the Third Community Empowerment and Local
            Governance Project (CEP III) had the following ratings:
            unsatisfactory outcome, unlikely sustainability, modest
            institutional development impact, unsatisfactory Bank
            performance, and not rated (CEP I), satisfactory (CEP II),
            and satisfactory (CEP III) Grantee performance.  The
            Agricultural Rehabilitation Project had the following
            ratings: moderately satisfactory outcome, unlikely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impact,
            satisfactory Bank performance, and not rated Grantee
            performance.  The Second Agricultural Rehabilitation Project
            had the following ratings: moderately unsatisfactory
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, modest institutional
            development impact, unsatisfactory Bank performance, and
            satisfactory Grantee performance. Experience with these
            projects highlights the following lessons: 1) With its
            global outreach and the expertise and experience of its
            staff the Bank is well positioned to make a substantial
            contribution to post-conflict reconstruction and
            development.  However, the experience of the three community
            empowerment and the two agriculture rehabilitation projects
            shows that careful thought to suitability of design and
            strategies to country conditions is paramount, especially
            where country capacity is weak; 2) even in the case of
            post-conflict Timor-Leste, where sophisticated monitoring
            and evaluation was impractical, there was a need to have a
            system to track project inputs, outputs, and outcomes and
            provide information about the adaptations needed in project
            design to ensure that the project objectives and activities
            are in keeping with the emerging institutional context and
            the absorptive capacity of the country; 3) particularly in
            post-conflict environments, an approach to capacity building
            that considers the underlying capacity in the country as
            well as how it would be promoted by the various donors is
            critical; and 4) the experience of Timor-Leste highlights
            the critical importance of coordinating multi-agency
            reconstruction efforts more effectively in a newly
            independent post-conflict country.

repnme.cdata!:
Timor Leste - Community Empowerment and
            Local Governance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Although the project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, supported by satisfactory performances, both
            by the Bank and Borrower, sustainability is unlikely and
            institutional development impacts are only modest. A number
            of lessons of relevance to future operations in Timor-Leste
            and to operations in other post-conflict situations are
            provided, lessons especially important in three areas: local
            governance and institutional development (including in
            regards to the role of women), project management and the
            relations with the Government, and the revolving funds. The
            lack of governmental presence at local levels in the
            post-conflict situation requires that careful thought be
            given to how local level institutional development can later
            be related, to the extent possible, to emerging
            administrative or representative structures, in order to
            avoid competing authorities, side-lining of local
            non-governmental institutions developed, or wasting capacity
            and skills developed at the local level, which could be of
            value to the emerging formal structures. Local capacity
            building should remain a priority throughout a project,
            particularly with regard to regular leadership training,
            gender sensitivity training, and training in participatory
            needs assessment, and project planning. It is important to
            keep the women in the mainstream of the development process:
            the establishment of one development council, rather than
            several bodies in the community, promoted the mainstreaming
            of women in community development. Gender disaggregating
            project data is a prerequisite for a development project,
            while lack of attention to this prevents management from
            recognizing, and addressing critical gender-related issues
            appropriately. Finally, it is essential to keep the local
            governance objective high on the project agenda, and to
            actively create awareness of this at the national, as well
            as local levels to ensure that lessons learned are
            integrated into the policies of the emerging government.

repnme.cdata!:
East Timor - Community Empowerment and
            Local Governance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Community Empowerment and Local
            Governance Project aims to strengthen local level social
            capital to build institutions that reduce poverty and
            support inclusive patterns of growth. The project consists
            of three components: a) Community Grants will support
            development proposals that are produced by villagers for the
            public good of their communities. Through district level
            technical specialists and local level facilitators it will
            provide village men and women with the information,
            opportunity, and freedom of choice that they need to make
            informed, responsible, proposals and decisions. b) Cultural
            heritage will support core activities as follows: i) A small
            grants program managed by a non-profit Timorese cultural
            heritage trust will support community-based cultural
            development programs. ii) The development of a national
            heritage and performance center will include a small
            vocational school, rotating displays, and a series of
            gallery and performance spaces where international and
            Timorese artists can perform. c) Civil Society Support Fund
            will aid the development of regional and local Timorese
            civil society groups who play an important role in
            galvanizing the communities to work together on
            reconstruction, thus contribute to the project's
            objective to build social capital and ensure inclusive
            patterns of growth.
